comments:
Reported by Daniel Megert in bug 49379.

Bug 49379 comment 11:

"I have I20040204 and developping for the 3.0 stream works fine. However, since I
have to provide a fix for 2.1.3 I started my 2.1 maintenance workspace up using
I20040204. This works as expected. But when I try to launch a target workspace
using PDE's Run-time Workbench launch configuration (I clear the workspace) I get:

!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Feb 05, 2004 12:52:26.28
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to acquire application service
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:100)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581)

I deleted all possible .config directories  - no luck. Before the OSGI story I
was able to run my old workspace and also run targets. This is now no longer
possible."

Bug 49379 comment 12:

"Note: I now restarted my 2.1.x workspace using 3.0 M4, added a new Run-time
Workbench launch config (as I did before) and it works like a charm hence I
assume this to work with latest 3.0 builds as well."

"...I started my 2.1 maintenance workspace..."

The problem you described shows that the runtime for 3.0 is being used to start
Eclipse from Eclipse (not what you want). 

Can you confirm you have only 2.1.* plugins in your launch configuration (either
by importing from a 2.1.* install, having a 2.1.* as target platform, or
checking them out from CVS)?

I guess I found the problem: the target platform was I20040204 and hence it used
this one for launching. I changed the target platform to be 2.1.2 and now it works.

I can't tell for sure but I think PDE automatically "updated" the target
workspace and launch config.

Ok, this is good. I will close this one. Feel free to open a different issue
against PDE/UI.

Agree.

FYI: I guess PDE automatically updates the target unless set manually. I did not
notice this since I launch without any external plug-in from the target location
(I have everything in the 2.1.2 workspace). BUT: the target seems to have an
effect on the  Run-time launch config behavior itself.

There were a number of changes in PDE to handle the new launch requirements for 
the 3.0 runtime.  PDE detects the flavour of target and uses different 
techniques depending on the target.  So yes, the nature of your target does 
affect how the target is launched.

As for updating the target automaticaly, you would have ot ask the PDE folks 
but there is a "use this applicaiton as the target" option.  If that is 
selected, I would expect it to be updated as I change what Eclipse I was using 
for the dev environment.

>but there is a "use this applicaiton as the target" option.  If that is 

Well that's what I did and that preference has gone and this probably triggered
the error.

The "Use this application" option was redundant and confusing to users.  PDE 
is able to determine this implicitly without confusing the user with two 
options.

Your host platform remains equal to your target platform, until you explicitly 
change the target platform value to a different one.
This way, if you launch different instances of Eclipse on the same workspace, 
every time your worbench opens, your target platform would be adjusted to be 
equal to your host platform (as if the old option were still there).

In your case, you launched a 3.0 platform on a 2.1 workbench, so the target 
platform is 3.0 and that is why you ran into the error.  No surprises there.  
It is the expected behavior since in this workspace, you had the default 
behavior (target == host).

If you do development for a 2.1 platform using a 3.0 host platform, you have 
to explicitly change the target platform in the preferences.  This is how 
things work and always have worked.

Dani, regarding comment #4, which is what is causing the confusion:
To be able to launch, PDE needs to specify the location of startup.jar.  This 
JAR is the one found in the target platform.
So when all your external plug-ins are uncheked, you would be running with 
workspace plug-ins only as you expect, but with the startup.jar of your target 
platform.

In the case here, the startup.jar is a 3.0 JAR which is incompatible with your 
2.1.x workspace plug-ins.  That is why it is necessary to always specify the 
target platform against which your workspace plug-ins are meant to be 
deployed, even if all the external plug-ins remain unchecked.

Wassim,

sounds all fair and I understand the technical implementation when reading your
comments BUT it is still confusing for a user (at least it was for me): I have
all needed plug-ins in my workspace and when running I have nothing checked from
the external plug-ins. Since I used 3.0 builds (before OSGi) to launch my
self-containing (at least I thought so ;-) 2.1.x workspace I saw no reason why
it should no longer work. Hence I filed the bug report.

If there is a dependency to the target location when launching then this should
be indicated somewhere in the launch configuration.

If your target platform is 3.0, and you did not have any of the osgi plug-ins 
checked, the launch certainly aborts/should abort with an error message.
Are you sure none of the external plug-ins were checked?  If so, then it's a 
valid bug.
also, were any of the osgi plug-ins in your workspace?
No external plug-ins checked and no OSGi stuff in the workspace.

Sounds like there is something in there with the preference going away.  If the 
workspace has no OSGi stuff and the target is a 3.0 platform, it should 
definitely bail.  Should be reasonably easy to reproduce this no?

the preference has nothing to do with it.  Theoretically, it should be easy to 
reproduce.

>and the target is a 3.0 platform,
I start with 3.0 but the code in the workspace is 2.1. The target is pointing to
3.0. Due to this the Run-time worbench launch config expects osgi stuff - at
least that's what I see.

Wassim, I have a question about the new UI: how do I restore the current
application as the target platform after it has been changed to something else?
It seems I have to find its location by hand (tried leaving the field empty, but
it didn't work).
Restore defaults didn't work as well. BTW, build is: N20040206.
Browsing to the location of your host Eclipse install location ought to do it.
Opened separate bug 51391 for this.

I imported org.eclipse.jdt.ui and all its pre-reqs from a 2.1.2 build into my 
workspace.I then changed the target platform to a 3.0 platform.

Scenario 1: I disabled all external (3.0) plug-ins.
When I tried to launch, the launch aborted with an error dialog saying that 
several osgi plug-ins are missing, which is the expected behavior that Dani 
claimed did not see.

Scenario 2: I enabled all external (3.0) plug-ins.
This time the launch proceeded of course because all the required plug-ins 
that OSGi requires are found (i.e. they are external and checked).  The 
workbench failed to start, again as expected, telling you to open the log.  
When you open the log, you will see that the 3.0 startup.jar obviously did not 
like the 2.1.2 core.runtime plug-in in my workspace.

Bottom line is that the user should be aware of a target platform really means.
In both scenarios however, there were enough details to figure out what is 
wrong.

Dani, you said that PDE allowed the launch to proceed even when all the 3.0 
external plug-ins are checked (i.e. you did not get the error dialog).  This 
is the reason why this bug report is open as PDE should warn if you are 
missing the crucial osgi plug-ins when launching against a 3.0 target platform.
Is there any other subtle yet important detail about your setup that could 
have caused this?

>scenario 1. Where did I say this? If I did so, then sorry - that was wrong
then. But when you look at comment 2 and comment 9 I describe that I have a self
containing workspace and cannot launch. Yes the dialog tells me about OSGi stuff
which is needed. Why? I have a self containing workspace. This only confused me
since the workspace worked for months like a charm.

>In both scenarios however, there were enough details to figure out what is 
>wrong.
I disagree ;-) 

Neither:

 A ava.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to acquire application service
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:100)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)

nor a dialog that tells me for my 2.1 workspace that OSGi plug-ins are needed
are enough detailed information - ok maybe detailed but not user friendly. 

In my opinion the user doesn't even need to be informed in any detail because he
 expects his workspace to simply startup. Assume: he never touched the PDE
target preference and was able to launch up to now, so saying the problem is the
user's side and he should have been smart enough to figure that out is just not
right. 
If he has to set the target property then he can expect a human readable dialog
which tells:

Launch failed. You are either missing some startup plug-ins (OSGi) for your 3.0
workspace or the PDE target preference does not point to the correct location.
However, up to now I thought that PDE could detect what's my workspace version
and also what's at the target location - but maybe that's not true. If you know
this information then you could include this information in the warning dialog.

>I have a self containing workspace and cannot launch.
As I said before, this is not quite true.  If you also had startup.jar in your 
workspace, then you would have a self-containing workspace.
You can't expect to run against the 3.0 startup.jar and not play by its rule.  

The fact of the matter is that being aware of the target platform is a 
requirement for any developer using Eclipse, if you are not going to have all 
your plug-ins in your workspace including the one supplying the startup.jar.

>If he has to set the target property then he can expect a human readable 
>dialog which tells...
A tad harsh...
Aborting the launch and telling you exactly what plug-ins you are missing from 
your configuration seems pretty reasonable.

>PDE could detect what's my workspace version and also what's at the target 
>location 
we can determine if your target platform is OSGi-based or not, and that is how 
we determine if we should do things in legacy mode or OSGi mode, since this is 
the platform against which you are supposedly developing your plug-ins.
What versions of plug-ins you are working on in your workspace is irrelevant 
and not taken into account. Your workspace plug-ins can have version 6.0 on 
them, for all we know (much like WSADIE).

Bottom line is that PDE does a lot magic behind the scenes and hides as many 
details as possible from the user, but at the very least one should be aware 
of a target platform is, as it is the foundation of our self-hosting story.
It does not seem to be too much to ask.

So you say I simply need to import the startup.jar in into the startup plug-in
which currently only holds the source and it works, right?

Yes, that is what I am claiming.  If you have the plug-in org.eclipse.platform 
in your workspace containing the startup.jar (in JAR or source form), you 
would run just fine.

actually, maybe it won't work.  But it should and hence we'll keep this bug 
report open ;-)

I always had org.eclipse.platform in my 2.1 workspace but this does not contain
the startup.jar. 

I now included the startup.jar manually and put it on the build path of
org.eclipse.platform

The existing configs can't be opened anymore and I cannot add new ones :-(
I could no longer add or delete any PDE launch config - even after deleting the
JAR again. Only changing the target preference to 2.1.2 fixed the problem again.

I knew something crazy like that might happen, but I guess comment #25 did not 
deter you from trying it <g>

I realized there is another problem.  The application that we launch is the 
one specified in the install.ini in your target platform.  So I believe we are 
finding org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench, while the one you want is the old 
org.eclipse.ui.workbench.

In any event, please target 2.1.2 for now (i.e. the way God intended people to 
self-host :-), and I will come up with a solution for a setup like yours.
Thanks, God ;-)

Fixed.
The problem that Dani reported in comment #26 is due to us counting on 
an "install.ini" file to be there, when it wasn't.

People should now be able to self-host without setting the target platform 
only if they have appropriate startup.jar imported into org.eclipse.platform 
in their workspace.

Dani, keep in mind, that, although this is now possible, it goes not only 
against the self-hosting rules of engagement, but also against the laws of man 
and nature :-)
